urn:contentItem:5PH3-2BS1-F0J6-J2V6-00000-00Controlled burns start2017-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:06ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Controlled burns startDerrick Krusche

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA will team up to conduct planned burns across the Ballarat region in coming weeks.

Ahead of what is forecast to be a fierce fire season, Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said residents must be prepared for whatever the season would bring.

"Planned burning activity is under way in regions where conditions have been suitable, so community members may be seeing or smelling smoke," she said.

"This spring, efforts will focus on reducing risk where we can.

"All indications are that it will be a longer and hotter summer than average.

"We need to act now to protect Victorian communities.

"Working with the CFA is a vital part of our planned burning program to make sure that we are using local knowledge to manage bushfire risk together to deliver maximum benefit to the community."

Controlled burning and other fuel management steps such as clearing, mowing and slashing are part of a big program to reduce bushfire risk for Ballarat residents and the environment.

Speaking with The Courier last week, Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said planned burns had been delayed due to dry weather in June and wet conditions in August.

Ballarat firefighters have previously urged landholders to register their own burn-offs to help avoid confusion if somebody calls triple-0 after seeing smoke.

A planned burn threatened buildings along Geelong Road at Mount Helen in July, requiring four fire trucks to control the blaze.

Weather conditions in Victoria appear likely to increase the risk of a dangerous bushfire season, with a potentially earlier start in some parts of the state, according to the latest bushfire season outlook.

For information, go to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:5RYT-DDY1-JD34-V4H3-00000-00Dry period for Grampians prompts burn-off warnings | Video2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:06ZLexisNexisNEWSDry period for Grampians prompts burn-off warnings | VideoErin Witmitz and Rex Martinich

WIMMERA emergency services have urged landowners to obey the law and get a permit for their farm burn-offs as the region nears its fourth month without substantial rainfall.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will start its extensive planned burning program across the region next month.

Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said the program would initially focus on reducing bushfire fuel in the Little Desert National Park. He said the program would then move to the Grampians National Park area from Halls Gap to Dunkeld and around Ararat and Stawell.

He said the program was similar to what they had done the past two to three years.

"It looks at more long-term fuel management," he said.

"It still really dry out there at the moment, so before we are burning, we will consider the weather and seasonal conditions.

"We work closely with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess weather conditions and will only do burns when conditions are suitable."

Mr Rudolph said the program would run from April to May. "People can go onto the fire ready app or the Forest Fire Management website to see where the burns area," he said.

"We aim to reduce the impact of smoke on communities.

"We understand that smoke from planned burns might cause concern for some people, but it's important that our crews take every opportunity while conditions are right to reduce bushfire risk."

Country Fire Authority district 16 operations manager Bernie Fradd said the fire danger period was still in force in the region.

"It's not the end of the fire danger period, so if you haven't got a permit to burn and you don't follow conditions stringently, you're still not allowed to light a fire in the open," he said.

Northern Grampians Senior Sergeant Brad Bennett said people need to apply through their council for a permit prior to any burning off.

"We'll be watching that very closely," he said.

"Apart form the criminal consequences, there is also the risk of property damage and danger to life so we will investigate any burning outside of permits."

urn:contentItem:5X1M-1PC1-JBJ7-N2TD-00000-00'It's going to be a bad year': Victoria's bushfire threat looms large2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:06ZLexisNexis'It's going to be a bad year': Victoria's bushfire threat looms largeLiam Mannix

Parts of Victoria face worst bushfire threat since Black Saturday left 173 people dead, with years of drought turning parts of the state into a tinderbox.

Parts of Victoria face their worst bushfire threat since Black Saturday left 173 people dead a decade ago, with years of low rainfall turning swaths of the state into a tinderbox.

Australia's year of record-breaking heat has set the scene for a monster fire season, experts warn, with forecasters tipping a hot, dry summer.

"This is potentially one of the worst droughts we have seen," says Dr Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Research Centre.

"It means that coming in to the start of the fire season, the vegetation is already very dry - probably the driest we have seen since the federation drought, if not longer."

"All indications are it's going to be a bad year."

The first six months of 2019 were the second warmest half-year on record across Australia and this year has also seen the highest average daytime temperatures and, over the southern half of Australia, the driest half-year since records began.

Victoria's forest fire danger index - the number authorities use to predict blazes - has reached its fourth-highest level on record. The other three times the index got this high the state saw disastrous blazes.

An unprecedented start to the fire season has seen more than 50 fires burning across NSW and Queensland this week, with almost 30 homes lost so far.

While eastern Australia's fire season typically starts in September, the extreme intensity of the blazes is unusual, experts say.

That's caused by a combination of long-term drought, a record-setting hot year and the long-term effects of the climate crisis.

In Victoria, East and West Gippsland and the Great Dividing Range face the biggest threats.

They are in their third year of below-average rainfall, leaving soils, grasses and trees parched.

The CFA has been forced to declare an early start to fire restrictions in East Gippsland. The restrictions will be in force from September 23.

Forests burnt during the Black Saturday bushfires in the state's central-eastern region have now fully recovered and are ready to burn again, Forest Fire Management Victoria warn.

A bushfire in this heavily wooded, heavily populated region is among the CFA's worst-case scenarios.

"Combine dry fuels with hot and windy conditions and you have perfect conditions for fires to start," says Dr Thornton. "And once they get started they are almost going to be impossible to pull up."

The spring forecast is not favourable. The Indian Ocean is in a positive dipole - its version of an El Nino - reducing expected rainfall in Australia.

Weather patterns in the Tasman Sea suggest there will be fewer cool southerly breezes. Forecasts released by the Bureau of Meteorology on Thursday suggested Victoria will see below-average rainfall and above-average temperatures throughout spring.

Despite official concerns, bushfire scientists have repeatedly warned that most Victorians ignore bushfire warnings until they are directly threatened by a blaze - putting lives at risk.

That left the CFA's chief officer, Steve Warrington, to issue a grim warning to Victorians who do not take steps to get out of harm's way earlier this year.

"We made it really clear - we won't be sending a fire truck up your street. We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay there after we'd advised you to leave."

urn:contentItem:5WXP-D1M1-F0J6-J0J0-00000-00Firewood collection to to begin on Sunday2019-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:27:06ZLexisNexisFirewood collection to to begin on Sunday

Legal collection of firewood will begin on Sunday, but restrictions will remain in Cohuna.

Only residents of Gannawarra Shire Council, Swan Hill Rural City, Loddon Shire and Shire of Campaspe can collect wood at the designated area at Cohuna.

People should only collect firewood from designated collection areas in State forests where collection is allowed and is for personal use only and cannot be sold, Forest Fire Management Victoria's Adrian Parker said.

"It is important to stay within collection limits, which are in place to prevent households stockpiling large volumes of firewood from public land and denying others a supply.

"Collection limits include taking a maximum of two cubic metres per person per day and a maximum of 16 cubic metres per household per financial year."

More news: Historic Manchester Arms Hotel is on the market

People cannot fell trees or cutting downed hollow logs for firewood, Mr Parker said.

Those collecting outside designated collection areas or season or taking too much can face fines of up to $8,261 or imprisonment.
